title: Santa Ana Volcano (Ilamatepec)
meta_title: Santa Ana Volcano — Eruption History, Height & Facts | VolcanoAtlas
meta_description: Santa Ana (Ilamatepec) is a 2,381 m active stratovolcano in El Salvador. Explore its eruption history, 2005 eruption, crater lake, hazards, and visitor guide.

quick_answer.what: Santa Ana (also known as Ilamatepec) is an active stratovolcano in western El Salvador, rising to 2,381 m (7,812 ft) — the highest point in the country.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted October 1, 2005, in a phreatomagmatic explosion that ejected crater lake water and killed two people. Currently quiescent with fumarolic activity.
quick_answer.famous_for: Being El Salvador's tallest and most voluminous volcano, with a dramatic nested summit crater containing an acid crater lake, and a history of eruptions dating to the 16th century.
quick_answer.danger_level: High — approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of the summit, including the city of Santa Ana (population ~275,000).

key_facts_box.region: Santa Ana Department, western El Salvador
key_facts_box.tectonic_setting: Subduction zone — Cocos Plate beneath Caribbean Plate, continental crust (> 25 km)
key_facts_box.summit_crater: Multiple nested crescentic craters with acid lake
key_facts_box.monitoring_agency: MARN (Ministerio de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales, El Salvador)

overview.content: Santa Ana, known locally as Ilamatepec, is an active stratovolcano and the highest point in El Salvador, reaching 2,381 m (7,812 ft) in the western part of the country. It is the most voluminous volcano in El Salvador, dominating the landscape west of the Coatepeque Caldera and the city of Santa Ana, El Salvador's second-largest city with approximately 275,000 residents. The broad summit is cut by several crescentic craters, the innermost of which contains a turquoise-colored sulfurous crater lake — one of Central America's most striking volcanic features. A 20-km-long fissure system extends from near the town of Chalchuapa to the northwest through the summit and down to the San Marcelino and Cerro la Olla cinder cones on the southeast flank, reflecting the regional tectonic stress pattern. Santa Ana has produced 18 recorded eruptions since the early 16th century, with the most recent being the phreatomagmatic explosion of October 1, 2005, which ejected hot lake water, rock, and mud, killing two people and displacing thousands. The volcano is part of the Ring of Fire and sits along the Central America Volcanic Arc, generated by the subduction of the Cocos Plate beneath the Caribbean Plate. Neighboring Izalco, which grew on Santa Ana's southeastern flank beginning in 1770, was once known as the 'Lighthouse of the Pacific' for its near-continuous incandescence.

geology_and_formation.content: Santa Ana is a massive, dominantly andesitic-to-trachyandesitic stratovolcano constructed within the Central America Volcanic Arc. The edifice represents hundreds of thousands of years of intermittent eruption and construction, building one of the largest volcanic structures in El Salvador. During the late Pleistocene, a major sector collapse on the southern flank produced a voluminous debris avalanche that traveled all the way to the Pacific Ocean, forming the Acajutla Peninsula — a feature that now constitutes one of El Salvador's principal port areas. Subsequent volcanic activity reconstructed much of the collapse scar, though the asymmetry remains visible in the volcano's profile. The summit region features multiple nested crescentic craters, each representing a different eruptive phase. The innermost crater hosts an acid sulfate lake approximately 200 m in diameter, fed by volcanic gases percolating through the hydrothermal system. The chemistry of this lake is closely monitored as an indicator of subsurface volcanic activity — changes in temperature, acidity, and dissolved gas concentrations can signal magmatic unrest. The prominent fissure system extending NNW–SSE across the edifice has produced numerous flank vents and cinder cones, including the Izalco cone that began growing in 1770 on the volcano's SSE flank and the San Marcelino vent that produced the notable 1722 lava flow.

eruption_history_overview.content: Santa Ana has 18 recorded eruptions in the Smithsonian database, spanning from uncertain activity around 1520 to the confirmed phreatomagmatic eruption of 2005. The eruption record is dominated by small to moderate explosive events, with six eruptions reaching VEI 3 — a relatively consistent explosive character over five centuries. Activity has occurred from both the summit craters and flank vents along the 20-km fissure system. The 16th century saw particularly frequent eruptions (1520, 1521, 1524, 1570, 1576), coinciding with the early Spanish colonial period and the first written documentation of volcanic activity in the region. After a period of reduced activity in the 17th century, eruptions resumed in 1722 with the notable San Marcelino flank eruption, and continued intermittently through the 19th century. The 20th century was relatively quiet until the explosive 2005 event, which provided a sharp reminder of the volcano's ongoing hazard potential.

subsections.title: The 1722 San Marcelino Eruption — The 13-Kilometer Lava Flow
subsections.content: On March 12, 1722, an eruption broke out not from Santa Ana's summit but from the San Marcelino cinder cone on the southeast flank. This fissure-fed eruption produced a substantial lava flow that traveled approximately 13 km eastward — a remarkable distance that testifies to the relatively fluid composition of the basaltic-andesite magma and the favorable slope gradient toward the lowlands. The San Marcelino flow remains one of the most prominent young lava features in El Salvador and is still clearly visible in the landscape today, contrasting with the surrounding agricultural land. The eruption was rated VEI 2 in the Smithsonian database, reflecting its predominantly effusive character, but the extensive lava flow destroyed villages and agricultural land over a wide area.

subsections.title: The 1874 and 1880 Eruptions — 19th Century Activity
subsections.content: Santa Ana produced a series of eruptions in the late 19th century, with VEI 3 events in 1874 and 1880. The 1880 eruption originated from the Mala Cara vent on the northwest flank, demonstrating the continued activity along the NNW–SSE fissure system. These eruptions produced moderate explosive activity with ashfall affecting nearby communities, though detailed records from this period in El Salvador are sparse. The 1879 and 1884 eruptions (both VEI 2) bracketed the larger 1880 event, suggesting a sustained period of heightened magmatic activity over roughly a decade.

subsections.title: The 2005 Eruption — Crater Lake Explosion and Modern Disaster
subsections.content: On October 1, 2005, Santa Ana produced a significant phreatomagmatic eruption that served as a stark warning of the volcano's hazard potential. The eruption, rated VEI 3, involved the explosive ejection of the summit crater lake water mixed with rock fragments, volcanic ash, and hot mud. The eruption column rose several kilometers above the summit, and hot lahars — mudflows composed of the ejected lake material mixed with volcanic debris — swept down the northern and southern flanks. Two people were killed, approximately 5,000 were evacuated from surrounding communities, and significant damage was inflicted on crops and infrastructure. The eruption was preceded by increased seismic activity and changes in the crater lake's chemistry, which had been detected by monitoring instruments in the weeks prior. The 2005 event highlighted the particular danger posed by crater-lake volcanoes: the rapid conversion of lake water to steam during a magmatic intrusion can dramatically amplify explosive energy, propelling lake sediment, acidic water, and rock fragments over large areas.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Since the 2005 eruption, Santa Ana has remained in a state of quiescence with persistent low-level fumarolic activity in the summit crater area. The acid crater lake has refilled and is continuously monitored for changes in temperature, color, and chemistry that could signal renewed magmatic activity. El Salvador's MARN operates seismic monitoring stations, gas measurement equipment, and webcams around the volcano. The relatively densely populated flanks and the proximity of the city of Santa Ana make this volcano a high-priority monitoring target. Scientists assess the probability of future eruptions as significant, given the volcano's consistent record of activity over the past five centuries, with an average recurrence interval of approximately 30–40 years between explosive events.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Santa Ana's hazard profile is defined by its large population exposure and diverse eruption styles. Approximately one million people live within 30 km of the summit, including the city of Santa Ana and numerous smaller communities on the volcano's fertile slopes. Primary hazards include explosive eruptions ejecting ballistic projectiles and pyroclastic material, lahars (particularly dangerous given the summit crater lake, which can amplify lahar generation), lava flows from flank fissures (as demonstrated by the 13-km San Marcelino flow of 1722), and ashfall affecting aviation and agriculture. The late-Pleistocene debris avalanche that formed the Acajutla Peninsula demonstrates that sector collapse is also a credible long-term hazard, though the probability of recurrence in any given human timeframe is low. El Salvador's CONRED and MARN maintain hazard maps and evacuation plans for communities in the highest-risk zones, particularly along drainage channels on the northern and southern flanks where lahars preferentially travel.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Santa Ana is a massive, broad-based stratovolcano dominating the landscape of western El Salvador. The volcano's base stretches approximately 20 km across, and its summit rises roughly 2,100 m above the adjacent Pacific coastal plain. The broad summit plateau is cut by several nested crescentic craters that step inward and downward, with the innermost crater hosting the distinctive turquoise acid lake. The lake, approximately 200 m in diameter, owes its vivid color to dissolved sulfur compounds and suspended mineral particles — its chemistry varies from pH 0.5 to 2.0, making it extremely corrosive. To the east, the massive Coatepeque Caldera (a separate volcanic feature) creates a dramatic landscape pairing, while the steep cone of Izalco rises prominently on the southeastern flank. The volcano's lower slopes are extensively cultivated, primarily with coffee at mid-elevations and sugarcane and other crops on the lower flanks, reflecting the rich volcanic soils.

cultural_significance.content: Santa Ana's indigenous name, Ilamatepec, derives from the Nahuatl language and means 'Old Woman Mountain' or 'Hill of the Old Woman' — a reference to the volcano's broad, maternal profile as seen from the surrounding lowlands. The volcano has been central to the cultural identity of western El Salvador since pre-Columbian times, and its eruptions during the early Spanish colonial period (1520s) are among the first documented volcanic events in the Americas. The city of Santa Ana, El Salvador's second-largest urban center, takes its name directly from the volcano. Today, the volcano and the adjacent Cerro Verde National Park are among El Salvador's premier natural attractions, and the crater lake hike is one of the country's most popular outdoor activities.

visiting_and_tourism.content: The hike to Santa Ana's crater lake is one of El Salvador's signature outdoor experiences. The trailhead is located within Cerro Verde National Park, and the well-maintained trail takes approximately 1.5–2 hours to ascend, passing through cloud forest before emerging onto the volcanic summit. Access is regulated: hikers must join organized groups that depart at scheduled times, accompanied by park rangers and police escorts for security. The summit crater provides a dramatic view of the turquoise acid lake below, with the cone of Izalco and the waters of Coatepeque Caldera visible in the broader panorama. The trail is moderately strenuous but non-technical, suitable for reasonably fit visitors. Cerro Verde National Park itself offers additional hiking trails, orchid gardens, and birdwatching opportunities. The nearby town of Juayúa on the Ruta de las Flores is a popular base for the hike.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Santa Ana sits in one of the most volcanically dense regions of Central America. Izalco, sometimes called the 'youngest volcano in El Salvador,' grew on Santa Ana's southeastern flank beginning in 1770 and erupted almost continuously until 1966. The Coatepeque Caldera, a large collapse feature immediately to the east, contains a scenic lake and represents a much older and larger-scale volcanic system. San Salvador volcano (also known as Quezaltepec) looms over the national capital, while San Miguel (Chaparrastique) is one of the most active volcanoes in the eastern part of the country. Across the border in Guatemala, Santa María and Fuego continue the Central America Volcanic Arc.

etymology.content: The volcano carries two names: Santa Ana, after the Catholic saint and the adjacent city founded by Spanish colonists, and Ilamatepec, from the Nahuatl words 'ilamat' (old woman) and 'tepec' (hill or mountain), meaning 'Old Woman Mountain.' The indigenous name reflects the volcano's broad, squat silhouette as viewed from the Pacific lowlands.

eruptions_per_century.note: Frequent activity during early colonial period

facts: Santa Ana (Ilamatepec) is the highest point in El Salvador at 2,381 m (7,812 ft) and the country's most voluminous volcano.
The volcano's summit crater contains a vivid turquoise acid lake with pH values as low as 0.5 — one of the most acidic crater lakes in Central America.
In the late Pleistocene, a massive sector collapse sent a debris avalanche all the way to the Pacific Ocean, forming the Acajutla Peninsula where El Salvador's principal port now operates.
The 1722 eruption from the San Marcelino flank vent produced a lava flow that traveled 13 km — one of the longest young lava flows in El Salvador.
Santa Ana has a 20-km-long fissure system extending from near Chalchuapa in the northwest through the summit to the San Marcelino cones on the southeast flank.
The 2005 phreatomagmatic eruption ejected the crater lake, sending hot acidic mudflows down the flanks that killed 2 people and displaced approximately 5,000.
Izalco volcano, once called the 'Lighthouse of the Pacific,' grew on Santa Ana's southeastern flank beginning in 1770 — essentially a parasitic cone of the larger volcano.
The indigenous Nahuatl name Ilamatepec means 'Old Woman Mountain,' describing the volcano's broad, low-angle profile.
Approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of Santa Ana's summit, making it one of the most population-exposed volcanoes in Central America.
El Salvador has 16 Holocene volcanoes in just 21,041 km² — one of the highest volcanic densities per unit area of any country on Earth.
Santa Ana has produced 18 recorded eruptions over 500 years, with six reaching VEI 3 — a remarkably consistent level of explosive activity.
The volcano's fertile slopes support some of El Salvador's most productive coffee-growing regions, particularly on the cooler upper flanks.

faqs.question: Is Santa Ana volcano active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Santa Ana (Ilamatepec) is an active stratovolcano in El Salvador. Its most recent eruption occurred on October 1, 2005, when a phreatomagmatic explosion ejected the summit crater lake and produced hot mudflows that killed two people. The volcano has 18 recorded eruptions since the 16th century, with activity occurring from both the summit and flank fissure vents. Currently, Santa Ana shows persistent low-level fumarolic activity and its acid crater lake is continuously monitored for signs of renewed unrest by El Salvador's MARN.

faqs.question: How tall is Santa Ana volcano?
faqs.answer: Santa Ana stands at 2,381 m (7,812 ft) above sea level, making it the highest point in El Salvador. The summit rises approximately 2,100 m above the adjacent Pacific coastal plain, giving it considerable topographic prominence. Despite being the country's tallest peak, Santa Ana's broad profile makes it appear less dramatic than steeper cones like neighboring Izalco (1,950 m), which grew on Santa Ana's southeastern flank.

faqs.question: When did Santa Ana last erupt?
faqs.answer: Santa Ana last erupted on October 1, 2005, in a VEI 3 phreatomagmatic explosion. The eruption involved the explosive ejection of the acidic crater lake water mixed with rock and volcanic material. Hot lahars swept down the flanks, killing two people and forcing the evacuation of approximately 5,000 residents. The eruption was preceded by detectable seismic unrest and changes in crater lake chemistry. Before 2005, the most recent confirmed eruption was a VEI 2 event in 1954.

faqs.question: Can you hike Santa Ana volcano?
faqs.answer: Yes, the hike to Santa Ana's crater lake is one of El Salvador's most popular outdoor activities. The trail begins in Cerro Verde National Park and takes approximately 1.5–2 hours to reach the summit crater, where hikers are rewarded with views of the turquoise acid lake and panoramic vistas of Izalco volcano and Coatepeque Caldera. Access is regulated — hikers must join organized groups with park ranger and police escorts. The trail is moderately strenuous but non-technical, passing through cloud forest.

faqs.question: What does Ilamatepec mean?
faqs.answer: Ilamatepec is the indigenous Nahuatl name for Santa Ana volcano, derived from 'ilamat' meaning 'old woman' and 'tepec' meaning 'hill' or 'mountain' — thus 'Old Woman Mountain.' The name describes the volcano's broad, low-angle silhouette as viewed from the surrounding lowlands, which contrasts with the steeper profile of its neighboring parasitic cone, Izalco. The Spanish name Santa Ana refers to the Catholic saint and the nearby city.

faqs.question: How dangerous is Santa Ana volcano?
faqs.answer: Santa Ana is considered one of the most hazardous volcanoes in El Salvador due to its large population exposure — approximately 1 million people live within 30 km of the summit, including the city of Santa Ana with ~275,000 residents. Hazards include explosive eruptions, lahars amplified by the crater lake, lava flows from flank fissures, and ashfall. The prehistoric debris avalanche that formed the Acajutla Peninsula demonstrates the potential for catastrophic sector collapse, though such events are extremely rare.

faqs.question: What is the crater lake at Santa Ana?
faqs.answer: Santa Ana's summit contains a vivid turquoise-colored acid crater lake approximately 200 m in diameter, nestled within the innermost of several nested crescentic craters. The lake is extremely acidic, with pH values ranging from 0.5 to 2.0, due to volcanic gases (primarily sulfur dioxide and hydrogen sulfide) dissolving into the water from the underlying hydrothermal system. The lake's temperature, color, and chemistry are monitored as indicators of volcanic unrest — the 2005 eruption violently ejected this lake in a phreatomagmatic explosion.

schema_data.name: Santa Ana
schema_data.description: Active stratovolcano and highest point in El Salvador, featuring an acid crater lake and 18 recorded eruptions since the 16th century
